claims.claim_text: A stack is a type of data structure that follows the principle of "Last In, First Out" (LIFO). It stores data items with operations like pushing (adding) and popping (removing) from its top. This makes it useful for tasks where the order of removal matters, such as undoing actions in a computer program.
claims.top_evidence:
NOTES:
Stack A stack is a linear data structure which is used to store data items and follows the principle of Last In - First Out (LIFO). First In - Last Out (FILO): It is a considered list in which addition of new data items and deletion of existing data items is done from one end known as the top of the stack. The insertion and deletion operations in stack are known as push and pop operations.

claims.claim_text: A Last In - First Out (LIFO) data structure is a way to store information in a stack, where the last item added is the first one to be removed. This principle is often used in programming and follows simple operations called push (adding an item) and pop (removing an item).
claims.top_evidence:
NOTES:
Stack A stack is a linear data structure which is used to store data items and follows the principle of Last In - First Out (LIFO). First In - Last Out (FILO): It is a considered list in which addition of new data items and deletion of existing data items is done from one end known as the top of the stack. The insertion and deletion operations in stack are known as push and pop operations.

claims.claim_text: First In - Last Out (FILO) is a principle that prioritizes the order in which items are removed from a data structure, such as a stack. In a FILO system, the last item added to the stack is the first one to be taken out. This is useful when managing tasks or data operations where the most recent entries should be processed first.

The insertion and deletion operations in stack are known as push and pop operations.

claims.claim_text: The "Top of the Stack" refers to the last item added in a stack, which is the first one to be removed. This concept is crucial as it follows the Last In - First Out (LIFO) principle common in stacks.

claims.claim_text: A linear data structure is a type of organization for storing information sequentially, where each element has exactly one successor or predecessor. Examples include arrays, linked lists, and stacks (which follow the principle of Last In - First Out, with push and pop operations).

First In - Last Out (FILO): It is a considered list in which addition of new data items and deletion of existing data items is done from one end known as the top of the stack. The insertion and deletion operations in stack are known as push and pop operations.

claims.claim_text: A Data Item is a single piece of information stored in a computer system, such as a number, letter, or symbol. In the context of a stack (a data structure used for storing and retrieving data), each item added or removed is referred to as push or pop operations.
